newsitem.title: LITHUANIA: LITHUANIAN ENERGY SHAREHOLDERS VOTE FOR REORGANISATION.
newsitem.headline: LITHUANIAN ENERGY SHAREHOLDERS VOTE FOR REORGANISATION.

text.p: Lithuanian Energy said on Friday that its general shareholders' meeting decided to reorganise the firm by splitting the heating arm to 17 firms controlled by municipalities.
"The heating sector of Lithuanian energy will be passed to six regional and 10 district companies," Kazys Kaikaris, the assistant director general of the comapny, told Reuters.
The new companies are to assume proportionally part of Lithuanian Energy's share capital, profit or losses and legal financial obligations as of May 1, 1997.
"The reorganisation of the company will come into effect from July 1," Kaikaris added.
The current share capital of Lithuanian Energy, the biggest firm in the country, stands at 2.8 billion litas and it will amount to 1.8 billion litas after the reorganisation, Kaikaris said.
The government owns over 90 percent of the firm.
The government said earlier the move was necessary to decentralise the country's inefficient and costly energy sector.
Lithuanian Energy said earlier that in the first quarter of 1997 it suffered 49.1 million litas of losses from operating the heating sector.
The electric energy production resulted in 47.1 million litas in profit in the first three months of the year.
The trade in the company's stocks on the Vilnius bourse is suspended now due to the reorganisation.
